### What version of `drizzle-kit` are you using?

0.21.1

### Describe the Bug

When I run `drizzle-kit push` in an empty Supabase database, it is comparing my schema with Supabase's own schemas.

Drizzle should not consider about other schemas than the main schema, unless it is specified.

### Environment & setup

```
OS: macOS 14.4.1  arm64
Node: v20.12.1
```

This issue was originally opened on the drizzle-orm repo. https://github.com/drizzle-team/drizzle-orm/issues/2312

title: `drizzle-kit generate` doesn't detect changes to columns when table has been renamed
body:
I just did a rather large migration where I renamed one of the core concepts in my application. This resulted in multiple tables (e.g., `houses` became `buildings`) and a few properties on those tables (e.g., `house_id` became `building_id`) being renamed.

After running `drizzle-kit generate`, I was asked which tables to drop/rename, and I selected all the relevant tables there. Then, the migration was generated, and I thought I was done.

That's when I realized that the columns in those tables hadn't been touched. The snapshot had been updated and now included the names of the renamed columns but the `.sql` file didn't contain any statements to modify them.

### Expected behavior

`generate` first asks about the renamed tables and then does another diffing pass and asks about the renamed columns in those tables. The resulting migration updates both the table and the column names and the snapshots is updated as expected.

**Alternatively** (this could be a temporary fix): The resulting migration only updates the table names but the snapshot also reflects that (i.e., the old column names are retained). This would allow running `generate` again to then update the column names as part of a second migration.

### Actual behavior

`generate` only asks about the renamed tables. The resulting migration only updates the table names and the snapshot is brought into an incorrect out-of-sync state (which means that a second `generate` pass couldn't fix the drift).

### Version

I used version `0.21.2` of `drizzle-kit`.

title: `drizzle-kit generate` fails to update the snapshot when no SQL is generated (renaming an enum)
body:
MVP reproduction instructions

Start from a naive schema that contains an `pgEnum`
```ts
import {
  pgTable,
  uuid,
  pgEnum,
} from "drizzle-orm/pg-core";

export const statusEnum = pgEnum("status", [
  "active",
  "inactive",
]);

export const persons = pgTable("user", {
  id: uuid("id").primaryKey(),
  status: statusEnum("status"),
});
```

Generate the migration by running `drizzle-kit generate`.

<details>
<summary>Click here to see the generated migration</summary>

```sql
DO $$ BEGIN
 CREATE TYPE "public"."status" AS ENUM('active', 'inactive');
EXCEPTION
 WHEN duplicate_object THEN null;
END $$;
--> statement-breakpoint
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "user" (
	"id" uuid PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
	"status" "status"
);
```
</details>

Then, rename the enum and make no other changes to the database.

```ts
export const statusEnum = pgEnum("newName", [
  "active",
  "inactive",
]);
```

The expected behavior here is that it renames the enum, and indeed, when you run `drizzle-kit generate` it asks if the field was renamed. Select the rename option (vs. the 'its new' option, it works fine)

```bash
$ npx drizzle-kit generate
drizzle-kit: v0.21.4
drizzle-orm: v0.30.10

No config path provided, using default 'drizzle.config.ts'
Reading config file 'drizzle.config.ts'
~ status › newName enum will be renamed/moved
--- all enum conflicts resolved ---

1 tables
user 2 columns 0 indexes 0 fks

No schema changes, nothing to migrate 😴
```

It identifies that there's a rename to do, says "enum will be renamed" and then exits with no schema changes. This seems to be because it decides that no SQL needs to be emitted.

Now, the problem: because that does not result in an update to the `snapshot` state, the next time you run, it asks the same question. 

On a team with multiple engineers contributing schema changes, it effectively defers that original decision ("was this renamed?") to the next engineer who makes a change.

I think if there's no SQL emitted, it should generate a blank or no-op SQL file and an updated snapshot anyway. That way the state of the codebase can adequately capture the decision made (and, e.g., be committed to git).

title: proposal: make drizzle-kit generate command smarter
body:
let's suppose I need to change a column type from int to uuid. currently, the generated migration only changes the column type, what will break.

```sql
ALTER TABLE "users" ALTER COLUMN "id" SET DATA TYPE uuid
```

But I assume it should generate something like that:

```sql
-- Step 1: Add a new UUID column
ALTER TABLE "users" ADD COLUMN "new_id" uuid DEFAULT gen_random_uuid();

-- Step 2: Populate the new UUID column for existing rows
UPDATE "users" SET "new_id" = gen_random_uuid();

-- Step 3: Drop the original integer id column
ALTER TABLE "users" DROP COLUMN "id";

-- Step 4: Rename the new UUID column to id
ALTER TABLE "users" RENAME COLUMN "new_id" TO "id";

-- Step 5: Set the new id column as primary key (if it was previously the primary key)
ALTER TABLE "users" ADD PRIMARY KEY ("id");
```

does it make sense?

title: [FEATURE] config dialect: export type
body:
using 
```
    "drizzle-orm": "^0.30.10",
    "drizzle-kit": "^0.21.4",
```

i'm trying to dynamically setup the config for drizzle-kit and this includes passing the dialect as string (e.g. 'postgresql')

sadly this wont work 
```
  dialect: db_conn.dialect // a string, croaks as it is not a drizzle-kit Dialect type
```

while the Dialect type is exportable from drizzle-orm this is not the same as drizzle-kit
(drizzle-orm uses 'pg' while drizzle-kit uses 'postgresql')

the dialect property is typed locally in drizzle-kit
```
declare const dialect: zod.ZodEnum<["postgresql", "mysql", "sqlite"]>;
type Dialect = TypeOf<typeof dialect>;
```

so this works fine:
```
import { defineConfig } from 'drizzle-kit';
import type { Dialect } from 'drizzle-kit';
export default defineConfig({
  dialect: db_conn.dialect as Dialect,
[..]
```

there is a warning however as Dialect from drizzle-kit is only available locally
do you think you could export the Dialect then we can use it without warnings?

(btw, was it intentional for the Dialect types of drizzle-kit and drizzle-orm to differ?)

title: Issues with ESBuild Register
body:
There's an issue with `esbuild-register` that's impacting our ability to use drizzle-kit, the TL;DR; is esbuild-register doesn't seem to [resolve the project's tsconfig file correctly](https://github.com/egoist/esbuild-register/issues/38).

Did some instrumenting and observed that it fails to bubble up looking for a `tsconfig.json` for the project when running `drizzle-kit`:

```
Reading config file '/Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/libs/database/drizzle.config.ts'
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/libs/database/tsconfig.json
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/configs/tsconfig.json
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/configs/tsconfig.json
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/configs/tsconfig.json
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/configs/tsconfig.json
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/configs/tsconfig.json
loading /Users/jack/dev/marketplace/backend/configs/application/tsconfig.json
Error: Transform failed with 4 errors:
 ... ERROR: Transforming JavaScript decorators to the configured target environment ("es2021") is not supported yet
```

It seems like `esbuild-register` searches the local directory of the file under compilation for a `tsconfig.json`, and if not found, uses the default tsconfig settings. Our problem is that `backend` is a nest project that makes heavy use of decorators. `experimentalDecorators` is not a default tsconfig option and hence esbuild fails to compile the drizzle config file.

The original `esbuild-register` issue suggested this can be worked around by doing the tsconfig resolution yourself and passing that as an option to esbuild, bypassing its resolution of the `tsconfig.json`.

title: Bug - ENUM modification not showing correctly in database and migrations
body:
Addition to ENUMs are reflected in the database and the migration files, but if I remove any values from the enum, SQL statements to remove those values are not generated and the old value can still be used in the database. 


Example - 
Let's say this is my enum

```
export const alertType = [
  'GEOFENCE',
  'SPEEDING',
  'BATTERY_LEVEL',
  'MILEAGE',
  'POWER_DISCONNECT',
] as const; 

export const alertTypeEnum = pgEnum('alert_types', alertType); 

```
If I update the enum field BATTERY_LEVEL to LOW_BATTERY, the migration adds the LOW_BATTERY field to the enum but does not remove BATTERY_LEVEL. 

SQL Generated - 
`ALTER TYPE "alert_types" ADD VALUE 'BATTERY_LEVEL';
` 

Expected Behavior 
BATTERY_LEVEL field from the ENUM should be removed.

title: generate `create foreign key` sql after `create index` sql on migration
body: Currently, migrations will generate `create foreign key` before `create index`, which causes errors when consuming generations if some foreign keys rely on fields that are not created index by default.

title: Bug Report: UUID Casting Issue in Drizzle KIT with PostgreSQL preventing updates and deletes
body:
### Bug Report: UUID Casting Issue in Drizzle Kit (Studio) with PostgreSQL

#### Issue Description
It seems the system is not casting correctly UUID fields as ::UUID, and that prevents update or deleting created records using drizzle-kit studio. 

#### Environment
- **PostgreSQL Database**: Deployed in ServerlessV2 with Data API
- **AWS SDK**: 
  - `@aws-sdk/client-rds-data`: `^3.577.0`
- **Drizzle Versions**: 
  - `drizzle-kit`: `^0.21.1-674c9c2`
  - `drizzle-orm`: `^0.30.10`

#### Configuration

```typescript
import { Resource } from "sst";
import { defineConfig } from "drizzle-kit";

export default defineConfig({
  driver: "aws-data-api",
  dialect: "postgresql",
  dbCredentials: {
    database: Resource.DatabaseRel.database,
    secretArn: Resource.DatabaseRel.secretArn,
    resourceArn: Resource.DatabaseRel.clusterArn,

  out: "./packages/core/migrations",

title: Enable DDL statement logging during `migrate` command
body:
Logging the DDL statements executed during a migration will greatly help troubleshooting, debugging, and manually recovering from a failed migration.

The current behaviour just appears to log the last error received from the database driver. If the error contains some identifiable context, maybe that helps, but if the error is more generic, we are completely lost.

Current behaviour when an error occurs:
- We don't know which migration files were executed (ie. `0012_funky_horse_calipers.sql` worked but `0013_sad_panda_noises.sql` failed)
- We don't know which DDL statement within a migration fail caused the error.

I suggest that when `config.verbose` is false, the `migrate` command should just log the name of each migration file before its DDL statements are executed. When `config.verbose` is true, the `migrate` command should also log each DDL right before it is executed. Then the `migration` command output should be detailed enough to troubleshoot the problem.

Here is an example error (caused by a manual edit of a migration file which was pushed without a local test)
```
npx drizzle-kit migrate --config=drizzle.config.ts
drizzle-kit: v0.21.2
drizzle-orm: v0.30.10

Custom config path was provided, using 'drizzle.config.ts'
Reading config file '{redacted}/drizzle.config.ts'
Using 'pg' driver for database querying
[⣷] applying migrations...error: type "bermy" does not exist
    at /{redacted}/node_modules/drizzle-kit/bin.cjs:62266:21
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at <anonymous> ({redacted}/node_modules/src/pg-core/dialect.ts:89:7)
    at NodePgSession.transaction ({redacted}/node_modules/src/node-postgres/session.ts:155:19)
    at PgDialect.migrate ({redacted}/node_modules/src/pg-core/dialect.ts:82:3)
    at migrate ({redacted}/node_modules/src/node-postgres/migrator.ts:10:2) {
  length: 93,
  severity: 'ERROR',
  code: '42704',
  detail: undefined,
  hint: undefined,
  position: '209',
  internalPosition: undefined,
  internalQuery: undefined,
  where: undefined,
  schema: undefined,
  table: undefined,
  column: undefined,
  dataType: undefined,
  constraint: undefined,
  file: 'parse_type.c',
  line: '271',
  routine: 'typenameType'
}
```

My drizzle.config.ts is:
```ts
import 'dotenv/config';
import type { Config } from 'drizzle-kit';

export default {
  schema: './src/db/schema/schema.ts',
  out: './src/db/migrations',
  dialect: 'postgresql',
  dbCredentials: {
    url: process.env.DATABASE_URL as string,
  },
  verbose: true,
  strict: true,
} satisfies Config;
```

Thanks for the great work so far!

title: [BUG] check throws a zod validation error
[BUG & FIX] pg introspection: columns order in multicolumn indexes is not guaranteed
body:
In the function `fromDatabase2` from file `src/serializer/pgSerializer.ts`  (names taken from `bin.cjs`)

The query fetching indexes from postgres database retrieves rows without specifying the order:
```typescript
const dbIndexes = await db2.query(
              `SELECT t.relname as table_name, i.relname AS index_name, ix.indisunique AS is_unique, a.attname AS column_name
          FROM pg_class t
          JOIN pg_index ix ON t.oid = ix.indrelid
          JOIN pg_class i ON i.oid = ix.indexrelid
          JOIN pg_attribute a ON a.attrelid = t.oid AND a.attnum = ANY(ix.indkey)
          JOIN pg_namespace ns ON ns.oid = t.relnamespace
          WHERE ns.nspname = '${tableSchema}'
            AND t.relname = '${tableName}'
            and ix.indisprimary = false;`
            );
```

Then, indexes in json schema are constructed by pushing columns in that (random) order.
```typescript
indexToReturn[indexName4].columns.push(indexColumnName);
```

### Bug:
Columns order of multicolumn indexes is not guaranteed (this produce false positives in `drizzle-kit push`).

### Fix:
order rows by position of columns in indexes: 
```typescript
const dbIndexes = await db2.query(
              `SELECT t.relname as table_name, i.relname AS index_name, ix.indisunique AS is_unique, a.attname AS column_name, array_position(ix.indkey, a.attnum) as column_position
          FROM pg_class t
          JOIN pg_index ix ON t.oid = ix.indrelid
          JOIN pg_class i ON i.oid = ix.indexrelid
          JOIN pg_attribute a ON a.attrelid = t.oid AND a.attnum = ANY(ix.indkey)
          JOIN pg_namespace ns ON ns.oid = t.relnamespace
          WHERE ns.nspname = '${tableSchema}'
            AND t.relname = '${tableName}'
            AND ix.indisprimary = false
          ORDER BY column_position;`
            );
```

title: [BUG] A number value is specified as the default for a column of type char
body:
### What version of `drizzle-orm` are you using?

0.30.10

### What version of `drizzle-kit` are you using?

0.21.0

### What type of `database` are you using?

MySQL

### Describe the Bug

When the default value of a column of type varchar is a numeric string, the default function is passed a numeric value instead of a string when the introspect command is used to generate the schema.

This is caused by casting a string to a number without checking whether the column is of type char.

```ts
const newColumn = {
  default: columnDefault === null ? void 0 : /^-?[\d.]+(?:e-?\d+)?$/.test(columnDefault) && !columnType.startsWith("decimal") ? Number(columnDefault) : isDefaultAnExpression ? clearDefaults(columnDefault, collation) : `'${columnDefault}'`,
  autoincrement: isAutoincrement,
  name: columnName,
  type: changedType,
  primaryKey: false,
  notNull: !isNullable,
  onUpdate
};
```

### Expected behavior

If the column is a char type, the default is also specified as a string.

### Patch

The following patch can be applied as a workaround until this issue is resolved.

```diff
diff --git a/bin.cjs b/bin.cjs
index fef2511d2e2d69c877fc925c281d88aa828f150f..c0ecbb07b62c35b08b8ddf709a7b0a7b67e13aa7 100755
--- a/bin.cjs
+++ b/bin.cjs
@@ -15246,7 +15246,7 @@ We have encountered a collision between the index name on columns ${source_defau
           onUpdate = true;
         }
         const newColumn = {
-          default: columnDefault === null ? void 0 : /^-?[\d.]+(?:e-?\d+)?$/.test(columnDefault) && !columnType.startsWith("decimal") ? Number(columnDefault) : isDefaultAnExpression ? clearDefaults(columnDefault, collation) : `'${columnDefault}'`,
+          default: columnDefault === null ? void 0 : /^-?[\d.]+(?:e-?\d+)?$/.test(columnDefault) && !['decimal', 'char', 'varchar'].some(type => columnType.startsWith(type)) ? Number(columnDefault) : isDefaultAnExpression ? clearDefaults(columnDefault, collation) : `'${columnDefault}'`,
           autoincrement: isAutoincrement,
           name: columnName,
           type: changedType,
```

title: PostgreSQL, text array, migrations. `drizzle-kit generate` produces invalid syntax in migration `ALTER` statement
body:
An ALTER migration generated with `drizzle-kit generate` from a table schema like this:

```ts
pgTable("users", {
  ...
  permissions: text("permissions").array().notNull().default([]),
});
```

Produces a migration that looks like this:

```sql
ALTER TABLE "users" ADD COLUMN "permissions" text[] DEFAULT   NOT NULL;
```

Which produces an error in all recent Postgres versions I could test out including [16.3](https://www.postgresql.org/about/news/postgresql-163-157-1412-1315-and-1219-released-2858/).
 
```
ERROR:  syntax error at or near "NOT"
LINE 1: ... "users" ADD COLUMN "permissions" text[] DEFAULT   NOT NULL;
```

The correct syntax would include a `{}` Postgres [array literal](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/arrays.html#ARRAYS-INPUT).

title: [bug] `drizzle-kit push` fails on local sqlite3 attempt due to presence of @libsql/client package
body:
Attempting to run `drizzle-kit push` on a local sqlite3 db fails... because my project also has `@libsql/client` installed.

I have both `better-sqlite3` and `@libsql/client` packages installed... as I want to be able to run dev locally or remotely... as well as push locally or remotely.  I have different npm scripts that set up a `DB_ENV` variable to control how the config operates (see config file below).

Inspecting the code in the `connectToSQLite` function - it will attempt to create a libsql client based on the _presence_ of the `@libsql/client` package... and so my url field ends up being treated as a real url, rather than my local db location path, and so `parseUri` fails with `LibsqlError: URL_INVALID: The URL is not in a valid format`.

In this case, it seems that checking for the presence of a specific library being installed is a somewhat poor proxy for deciding what to do.  Would it be better to drive things more directly from config settings, rather than by checking which package(s) are installed? 


versions:
 
```
"drizzle-kit": "^0.21.1",
"drizzle-orm": "^0.30.10",
```

My `drizzle.config.ts`:

```
import type { Config } from 'drizzle-kit'
import dotenv from 'dotenv'

dotenv.config()

const remoteDB = process.env.DB_ENV === 'remote'

const config: Config = {
	schema: './src/db/schema/*',
	out: './drizzle/migrations',
	dialect: 'sqlite',
	...(remoteDB ? { driver: 'turso' } : {}),
	...(remoteDB
		? {
				dbCredentials: {
					url: process.env.DB_URL!,
					authToken: process.env.DB_AUTH,
				},
			}

	verbose: true,
	strict: true,

export default config

title: Change the schema creation SQL in PostgreSQL
body:
Currently the generated migration may contains a schema SQL if I use `pgSchema`.

For example, `export const schema = pgSchema('duoshuo');` will generate `CREATE SCHEMA "duoshuo";` in the migration file.

I think we should change it to `CREATE SCHEMA IF NOT EXISTS "duoshuo";`.

title: [bug]: `drizzle-kit push` is not detecting changes correctly (Turso)
body:
I'm using Turso in local development and attempting to use `drizzle-kit push` but it's not correctly detecting schema changes. For example, it won't simply detect a new column being added to a table. It does seem to detect changes to indexes and constraints. See an example below:

**Current Schema (already pushed to the database)**

```
export let example = sqliteTable('example', {
	id: text('id').primaryKey()
})
```

**Proposed Schema Change (without unique constraint)**
```
export let example = sqliteTable('example', {
	id: text('id').primaryKey(),
	extraField: text('extra_field')
})
```

Running `drizzle-kit push` on the above returns:
```
Reading config file '/***<projectpath>***/drizzle.config.ts'

[i] No changes detected
```

But, running `drizzle-kit push` on a change such as the following:

**Proposed Schema Change (with unique constraint)**
```
export let example = sqliteTable('example', {
	id: text('id').primaryKey(),
	extraFieldAndUnique: text('extra_field').unique()
})
```

Prompts the following, noting the creation of a new unique index **but** not the new column:
```
Warning You are about to execute current statements:

CREATE UNIQUE INDEX `example_extra_field_unique` ON `example` (`extra_field`);

  No, abort
❯ Yes, I want to execute all statements
```

**drizzle.config.ts**
```
export default defineConfig({
	dialect: 'sqlite',
	driver: 'turso',
	dbCredentials: {
		url: 'http://localhost:8080'
	},

	schema: './src/lib/server/database/schema/*.ts',
	strict: true,
	verbose: true
})
```

```
"drizzle-kit": "0.21.1",
"drizzle-orm": "0.30.10"
```

title: Drizzle Integration with Bun: async_hooks.createHook not supported and Missing Configuration File Error
body:
This issue reports two problems encountered when attempting to integrate Drizzle (versions drizzle-kit v0.20.18 and drizzle-orm v0.30.10) with the Bun JavaScript runtime:

## Bun Hook Warning:
Bun generates a warning message stating async_hooks.createHook is not implemented in Bun. This indicates that Drizzle might be relying on the async_hooks module for asynchronous I/O monitoring, which Bun doesn't currently support.
Missing Configuration File: Drizzle fails to find the default configuration file drizzle.config.json. The error message "Failed to find Response internal state key" might be related to this.
Expected Behavior:

Drizzle should run seamlessly within the Bun environment without warnings or errors.
If Drizzle cannot leverage async_hooks in Bun, it should fall back on alternative methods or provide a way to disable this functionality.
The default configuration file drizzle.config.json should be located and used as expected.
Additional Information:

Bun Version: (Please specify the Bun version you're using)
Drizzle Usage: (Briefly describe how you're using Drizzle in your Bun project)
Steps to Reproduce:

## Create a Bun project (if applicable).
Install Drizzle dependencies using bun install drizzle-kit drizzle-orm.
Attempt to run your Drizzle application using Bun's script runner (e.g., bun run generate).
Possible Solutions (to be explored):

### Investigate Drizzle's compatibility with Bun.
Explore alternative approaches for asynchronous I/O monitoring in Bun.
Create the missing drizzle.config.json file (if necessary).
Consider using Drizzle in a Node.js environment if Bun compatibility is a challenge.
We appreciate any insights or suggestions the community might have to resolve this issue and improve Drizzle's integration with Bun.

title: push command incorrectly detects changes
`drizzle-kit@0.21.0` uses `@libsql/client`, not installed in the workspace
body:
According to the `v0.21.0` [release note](https://github.com/drizzle-team/drizzle-kit-mirror/releases/tag/v0.21.0):

> For `sqlite` dialect, Drizzle will:
> 
> - Check if the `@libsql/client` driver is installed and use it.
> - If not, try to find `better-sqlite3` and use it.
> - If nothing is found, an error will be thrown

There seems to be a resolution error with the `pnpm` package manager.

Even in a workspace where `@libsql/client` is not installed as a (dev) dependency,

```shell
pnpm why better-sqlite3

# dependencies:
# better-sqlite3 9.6.0
# drizzle-orm 0.30.10
# └── better-sqlite3 9.6.0 peer

pnpm why @libsql/client

# dependencies:
# drizzle-orm 0.30.10
# └── @libsql/client 0.6.0 peer
```

The `drizzle-kit` commands (e.g. `migrate`, `studio`) finds it and uses it instead.

```
LibsqlError: URL_INVALID: The URL is not in a valid format
    at parseUri (file:///path-to-workspace/node_modules/.pnpm/@libsql+core@0.6.0/node_modules/@libsql/core/lib-esm/uri.js:9:15)
```

Ability to specify the `better-sqlite3` driver is no longer available.

title: sqlite alter column should list changes
body:
When you attempt to change the column type in a sqlite schema, then generate a migration file, this is the result:

```
/*
 SQLite does not support "Changing existing column type" out of the box, we do not generate automatic migration for that, so it has to be done manually
 Please refer to: https://www.techonthenet.com/sqlite/tables/alter_table.php
                  https://www.sqlite.org/lang_altertable.html
                  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2083543/modify-a-columns-type-in-sqlite3

 Due to that we don't generate migration automatically and it has to be done manually
*/
```

That's fine, I'd prefer if you generated the SQL for me but I guess I can do it manually.

But it'd be nice if the comment included the changes that must be completed manually. For example, `change column <xyz> from type <x> to type <y>`

title: sqlite migrations should be inside transaction
body:
It seems generated migration files aren't inside a transaction.

I think they should be.

- easier to recover from migration errors
- doesn't allow writes to the db when in the middle of a migration

title: sqlite push should be in transaction
body:
It seems the sql commands executed by push:sqlite aren't inside a transaction.

I'd expect them to be in a transaction, so that if I encounter an error part way through my database isn't left in a weird state and is instead rolled back to where it was prior to the push

title: No detected  schema when use bun --bun drizzle-kit push...
`.DS_Store` in migrations/meta breaks everything
body:
This one took me a while to figure out, but if there is a `.DS_Store` file in your meta directory, you can't run migrations anymore since it considers that file in the snapshots and can't parse it.

We should be filtering out files that start with `.` or look for that file specifically, or only be looking for JSON files.

title: BUG: drizzle-kit push:sqlite - Foriegn keys referencing __old_push_[table name] after
body:
## The Issue:
After making a change to the schema, and running drizzle-kit push:sqlite, Requests made from my application started getting the following error:
```error
 ⨯ Internal error: SqliteError: no such table: main.__old_push_[table name]
    at Database.prepare ([path to project]\node_modules\.pnpm\better-sqlite3@9.5.0\node_modules\better-sqlite3\lib\methods\wrappers.js:5:21)
    at BetterSQLiteSession.prepareQuery (./node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-orm@0.30.8_@types+better-sqlite3@7.6.9_@types+react@18.2.79_better-sqlite3@9.5.0_react@18.2.0/node_modules/drizzle-orm/better-sqlite3/session.js:28:30)
    at BetterSQLiteSession.prepareOneTimeQuery (./node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-orm@0.30.8_@types+better-sqlite3@7.6.9_@types+react@18.2.79_better-sqlite3@9.5.0_react@18.2.0/node_modules/drizzle-orm/sqlite-core/session.js:76:17)
    at QueryPromise._prepare (./node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-orm@0.30.8_@types+better-sqlite3@7.6.9_@types+react@18.2.79_better-sqlite3@9.5.0_react@18.2.0/node_modules/drizzle-orm/sqlite-core/query-builders/insert.js:135:81)
    at QueryPromise.run (./node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-orm@0.30.8_@types+better-sqlite3@7.6.9_@types+react@18.2.79_better-sqlite3@9.5.0_react@18.2.0/node_modules/drizzle-orm/sqlite-core/query-builders/insert.js:146:17)
    at QueryPromise.execute (./node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-orm@0.30.8_@types+better-sqlite3@7.6.9_@types+react@18.2.79_better-sqlite3@9.5.0_react@18.2.0/node_modules/drizzle-orm/sqlite-core/query-builders/insert.js:158:54)
    at QueryPromise.then (./node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-orm@0.30.8_@types+better-sqlite3@7.6.9_@types+react@18.2.79_better-sqlite3@9.5.0_react@18.2.0/node_modules/drizzle-orm/query-promise.js:26:17)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
digest: "3629522731"
```

## Environment
drizzle-kit version: 0.20.17
drizzle-orm version: 0.30.8
framework: NextJS

## Identified Bug:
The root cause of this error is the fact that the foriegn key values set up using the .references(()=>table.id) syntax in the schema are not being properly migrated, and are left referencing the __old_push_ version of the target table (which I assume only exists for a short time during the push:sqlite process)

## Work Around:
The foriegn keys were not really neccessary in my case, so I just removed the .references() calls in the schema and everything works now, but I imagine that wont be a good solution for everyone.

title: Support for PostgreSQL PostGIS with DB push
Allow sqlite foreign key constraints to be disabled and enabled in migrations (`PRAGMA foreign_keys`)
body:
The sqlite `migrate` uses a batch transaction to execute the migrations. 

However:

1. certain changes to sqlite databases with foreign key constraints enabled will need to use `PRAGMA foreign_keys = OFF` and `PRAGMA foreign_keys = ON` [https://www.sqlite.org/lang_altertable.html#making_other_kinds_of_table_schema_changes](url), and 
2. these `PRAGMA` statements are not supported inside transactions [https://www.sqlite.org/pragma.html#pragma_foreign_keys](url).

One idea is to script a transaction for each migration in the generated migration sql file. Then in `migrate` detect these transactions and execute them using `batch`, whilst using `run` for all other statements outside the transaction. (The migration table `INSERT` would also have to be scripted into the migration sql file inside the transaction)

title: feature request: command and api to make a snapshot of schema
body:
For migrations drizzle uses snapshots based on provided schema for further diffing and migration generation

Snapshots as intermediate DL can be useful for additional tools (like prisma's model objects). Having a snapshot one can build a database diagram to visually inspect db design in progress, can make some additional types/crud/whatever code generators, etc

This already can be done for already migrated stuff, but for WIP – no. So I think it would be useful to have a cli command and an API to get only the snapshot of current schema, without writing it on disk and generating the migrations

MySQL introspection generates an invalid schema.ts when column names start with a number. MySQL permits column names to begin with a number, but drizzle-kit produces a schema.ts with object property names that start with a number, which JavaScript does not allow.

I understand that it may not be best practice to name columns starting with numbers but it would be beneficial if drizzle-kit could handle this edge case more robustly.

title: [SUGGESTION] drizzle.config.ts non-default export error description improvement
body:
After using `defineConfig()` to create my configuration for `drizzle.config.ts` , and using the command:
 ```
 drizzle-kit push:pg --config=<mypath>/drizzle.config.ts
 ```
I was met with a rather confusing error:
```
 Invalid input  Only "pg" is available options for "--driver"
```

This error was being caused because I had not defined my configuration as the default export of the file, I had instead exported it as a constant, as seen below:

```typescript
import { defineConfig } from "drizzle-kit"

import { env } from "~/env"

export const drizzleConfig = defineConfig({  //This line is causing the error
  schema: "./schema.ts",
  out: "./../../drizzle",
  driver: "pg",
  dbCredentials: {
    connectionString: env.POSTGRES_URL,
  },
  verbose: true,
  strict: true,
})
```

Eventually I spotted my fault and was easily able to stop the error occuring by removing the constant and just exporting the configuration as the default export directly. However the error description lead to me believing that something within my actual configuration definition was the error's cause, specifically the driver, and wasting a fair bit of time as a result.

I suggest that an improved error description be added such that if `drizzle.config.ts` is read in without a default export, the error description instead reads something along the lines of: `no default export found in 'drizzle.config.ts' , are you sure you exported config as default?`

title: Drizzle Studio giving error due to `CURRENT_TIMESTAMP` in schema
Documentation textfix: Launch Drizzle Studio
body:
![image](https://github.com/drizzle-team/drizzle-kit-mirror/assets/47607282/ff47ea16-8b15-4cdd-9339-4a4eafd72b51)

**Issue: Lack of Documentation Update when Switching Installation Options**

**Description:**
When attempting to change the installation option (for example, from npm to yarn) for the project, the installation documentation remains unchanged. This can create confusion among developers and make the project setup process challenging.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Go to the project's installation documentation page.
2. Try to change the installation option (for example, switch from npm to yarn).
3. Notice that the documentation remains unchanged, regardless of the selected installation option.

**Expected Behavior:**
The installation documentation should automatically update according to the selected installation option (npm, yarn, etc.) to provide accurate instructions for developers.

**Current Behavior:**
The documentation remains unchanged regardless of the selected installation option, which can lead to confusion and hinder the project setup process.

**Impact:**
This may slow down the project setup and configuration process and create confusion for new developers unfamiliar with the chosen installation option.

**Proposed Solution:**
Update the installation documentation to automatically adapt to the selected installation option, ensuring accurate instructions for developers.

**Priority:**
Medium

```
export const email = pgTable("Email", {
	id: serial("id").primaryKey().notNull(),
	uid: uuid("uid").notNull(),
	email: text("email").notNull(),
	type: emailType("type").notNull(),
	verifiedAt: timestamp("verifiedAt", { precision: 3, mode: 'string' }),
	verifyTokenGeneratedAt: timestamp("verifyTokenGeneratedAt", { precision: 3, mode: 'string' }),
	verifyToken: varchar("verifyToken", { length: 6 }),
	userId: integer("userId").notNull().references(() => user.id, { onDelete: "cascade" } ),
	isPrivate: boolean("isPrivate"),
	version: integer("version").default(1).notNull(),
	updatedAt: timestamp("updatedAt", { mode: 'string' }).defaultNow().notNull(),
	createdAt: timestamp("createdAt", { mode: 'string' }).defaultNow().notNull(),
	deletedAt: date("deletedAt"),
	isDeleted: boolean("isDeleted").default(false),
},
(table) => {
	return {
		uidUnique: uniqueIndex("Email_uid_unique").on(table.uid),
		emailUnique: uniqueIndex("Email_email_unique").on(table.email).where(eq(table.isDeleted,false)),
	}
});
```

migration output 

```
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS "Email_email_unique" ON "Email" ("email");--> statement-breakpoint
```

expected
```
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS "Email_email_unique" ON "Email" ("email") WHERE "isDeleted" = false;
```

title: Command "push:pg" attempting to apply changes even when there are no changes in the code

body:
I have been trying to get Drizzle working with Docker but no luck.

Every other framework has solutions for it but Drizzle lacks them.

I think what Drizzle Kit needs is a solution provided in these 2 blogs:

1. https://notiz.dev/blog/dockerizing-nestjs-with-prisma-and-postgresql
2. https://notiz.dev/blog/prisma-migrate-deploy-with-docker

The example is Prisma with Nestjs but it probably would work with Drizzle & Next.js.

I've been trying for a week to get Docker running on my simple SQLite + Next.js project but so far have been unsuccessful.

Part of the reason is Drizzle doesn't provide direct migrate command but instead wants me to rely on `tsx` which again breaks the build near the end as Dockerfile can't find `tsx` at the end.

Smallest Reproduction -> https://github.com/deadcoder0904/easypanel-nextjs-sqlite

This project works well in Development & would definitely work well in Production if I can get the migrate command.

Currently, I can think of only 1 solution:

1. Use bun.sh (as a `tsx` replacement) but it won't be available on Windows until 1 or 2 weeks anyways.

If there's any other solutions that anyone got Drizzle Migrations working with SQLite on a Next.js app, I'd love to know? I've found a couple of projects on Github but they do it in a very complicated manner.

I think the reason is because Drizzle Migrate doesn't exist as a command.

Here's how tsx fails:

```ts

"tags" text[] DEFAULT  NOT NULL

"tags" text[] DEFAULT array[]::text[] NOT NULL

title: [BUG]: push doesn't allow to add "not null" to the column without truncating the table
body:
If you have a nullable column in a table and add `.notNull()` to it, `drizzle-kit push` won't allow you to apply this change without truncating the table, even though technically it's possible to apply if that column doesn't contain null values.

Two potential solutions:
1. Check if the column contains null values before suggesting to truncate the table (the most correct)
2. Just remove the warning and run the operation regardless, which will either work or fail if the column has null values (less work)

0.29.3

### Describe the Bug
With the below piece of code, I'd expect the index_sessions_on_session_id index to be of type HASH, but the generated SQLs do not have the type, hence defaulting to BTREE.

```typescript
export const sessions = pgTable(
  "sessions",
  {
    sessionId: uuid("id").primaryKey().defaultRandom().notNull(),
    userId: bigint("user_id", { mode: "number" })
      .notNull()

      .defaultNow()
      .notNull(),

      .defaultNow()
      .notNull(),
  },
  (table) => {
    return {
      indexSessionsOnSessionId: uniqueIndex("index_sessions_on_session_id")
        .on(table.sessionId)
        .using(sql`hash`),
    };
  }
);
```

### Expected behavior
Expected generated SQL to be –

```sql
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS "index_sessions_on_session_id" ON "sessions" ("sessionId") USING HASH ("sessionId");

but instead it is –

```sql

title: Persistent Issue in Updating 'image' Column Default Value with Drizzle Kit in PostgreSQL Schema
body:
**Description:**
I am experiencing a recurring problem with Drizzle ORM when attempting to update the default value of the 'image' column in my PostgreSQL 'posts' table. Despite repeatedly running the update command, the change is not applied, and I am prompted each time to confirm the execution without any actual effect.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Initially define the 'posts' table with an 'image' column, setting a default value using Drizzle ORM.
2. Change the default value of the 'image' column and execute the `push:pg` command to apply updates.
3. Observe that the command prompts for confirmation to execute the changes.
4. After confirming, notice that the expected changes are not applied to the database.
5. On subsequent executions of the `push:pg` command, the same prompt appears and confirmation is requested, but the changes still do not take effect.

**Expected Behavior:**
The default value for the 'image' column in the 'posts' table should update according to the modified schema in Drizzle ORM, and the change should be reflected in the PostgreSQL database after executing the `push:pg` command.

**Actual Behavior:**
Despite confirming the execution of the `push:pg` command multiple times, the default value for the 'image' column remains unchanged. The command consistently prompts for confirmation as if the change has not been previously applied.

**Code Snippet:**
```typescript
export const posts = pgTable(
  "posts",
  {
    ...
    image: varchar("image", { length: 500 }).notNull().default(""),
    ...
  },
  ...
);
```

**Command Used:**
```bash
npx drizzle-kit push:pg --config drizzle.pg.config.ts
```

Repeatedly executing this command results in the following prompt without resolving the issue:
```
ALTER TABLE "posts" ALTER COLUMN "image" SET DEFAULT '';

  No, abort
❯ Yes, I want to execute all statements
```

**Version Information:**
- drizzle-kit: v0.20.10
- drizzle-orm: v0.29.3

title: We've found duplicated index name across public schema. Please rename your index in either the stations table or the table with the duplicated index name
BUG: generate:mysql outputs migration files without shema/database prefixes for unique indexes
body:
What version of drizzle-orm are you using?
0.29.2

What version of drizzle-kit are you using?
0.20.8

### Describe the Bug

Running 

`npx drizzle-kit generate:mysql`

generates migration files with non-unique indexes without schema/database prefixes:

``CREATE INDEX `some_index_name` ON `some_table` (`some_column`);``

In contrast to tables where the schema/database prefixes are present:

``CREATE TABLE `some_schema`.`some_table` ( ...);``

Note that unique indexes and primary keys are generated inside the "CREATE TABLE" statement.

### Expected behavior
I expect migration files with non-unique indexes including schema/database prefixes:

``CREATE INDEX `some_index_name` ON `some_schema`.`some_table` (`some_column`);``

### Environment & setup
Node v21.5.0
MacOS Sonoma 14.0
MySQL 8.2.0-1.el8

title: Autodetect dialect based on configured driver
body:
Most drizzle-kit commands require explicitly passing the dialect after a colon. However, for a configured database connection this dialect can already be inferred based on the selected driver (e.g. `driver: "better-sqlite"` corresponds to `foobar:sqlite`).

This would make the commands easier to use, especially when dealing with different databases between projects which currently means that one has to always look up which database is used to select the correct command.

Here is a [minimal reproduction](https://github.com/Bogdan-101/Drizzle-kit-default-varchar-bug)

When adding a default value to the varchar column and applying migrations after the db updated, drizzle-kit still thinks that the default value for the column is not set and asks whether you want to alter the column. You can apply this default value to the column as many times as you want - the message will always show up.

title: [FEATURE]: adding a --silent, --yes or --force option to drizzle push:<driver>
body:
When applying migrations to the db you are forced to review sql code that is about to be executed in your db. Even though I love this feature I cannot see any flag for the `push` command to accept all changes without an interactive cli. This may be required on ci/cd when migrating cloud database. There is a `strict` option available but I think you cannot use this variable to skip migrations review.
My suggestions for such flag are:
`yes, silent, force, no-verify`

Also in the [docs](https://orm.drizzle.team/kit-docs/commands/#prototype--push) in the usage example there is a `--ssl` option listed but it is not present in the `push` list of commands.

title: [Bug] Stop creating drizzle schema for migration hash tracking
body: Running [migrate](https://orm.drizzle.team/kit-docs/overview/#running-migrations) creates a new table `drizzle.__drizzle_migrations`. title: [BUG] Push: push:sqlite Codegen Problem When Pushing Adds New Fields
body:
Dependencies:
- `"drizzle-kit": "^0.20.6"`
- `"drizzle-orm": "^0.29.0"`

Issue Description:

When changing table schemas in SQLite, the push command line generates SQL like `INSERT INTO "table" SELECT * FROM "__old_push_table";`. However, this can cause problems if one tries to add new columns, as stated in the [SQLite documentation](https://www.sqlite.org/lang_insert.html).

> If no column-list is specified, the number of columns in the result of the SELECT must be the same as the number of columns in the table.

In my case, I added a new column between existing columns, where the preceding column has a NOT NULL constraint. This caused an error during the push operation:
```
SqliteError: NOT NULL constraint failed: task.created_at
at BetterSqlite.run (xxx/node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-kit@0.20.6/node_modules/drizzle-kit/bin.cjs:25489:32)
at Command.<anonymous> (xxx/node_modules/.pnpm/drizzle-kit@0.20.6/node_modules/drizzle-kit/bin.cjs:63284:33) {
code: 'SQLITE_CONSTRAINT_NOTNULL'
}
```

Additional Question:

Shouldn't an error thrown during the push operation be caught and trigger a rollback, instead of leaving the transaction incomplete?

title: BUG: v0.20.2 push:mysql error: there can be only one auto column and it must be defined as a key
body:
When pushing schema changes to a Planetscale database, drizzle-kit attempts to drop the primary key, resulting in an unexpected error that crashes the program and does not push schema changes.

---

- Windows 11 x64
- Node v20.8.0
- Planetscale DB
```sh
$ drizzle-kit -v

drizzle-kit: v0.20.2
drizzle-orm: v0.29.0
```

```ts
// drizzle.config.ts

import type { Config } from "drizzle-kit";
import "dotenv/config";

export default {
  schema: "shared/db-schema/schema.ts",
  driver: "mysql2",
  strict: false,
  dbCredentials: {
    uri: `${process.env.SECRET_DATABASE_URL_DK}?ssl={"rejectUnauthorized":true}`,
  },
} satisfies Config;
```

```ts
// schema.ts

import { int, mysqlTable, varchar } from "drizzle-orm/mysql-core";

export const registrationsT = mysqlTable("Registrations", {
  id: int("id").primaryKey().autoincrement(),
  eventId: varchar("eventId", { length: 20 }).notNull(),
});
```

## Reproduction Steps
1. Drop tables in database
2. `drizzle-kit push:mysql` - works as expected
```sh
$ drizzle-kit push:mysql

drizzle-kit: v0.20.2
drizzle-orm: v0.29.0

No config path provided, using default path

title: Generating Migrations: Update to 0.20.0 causes dropping of all tables except last declared Schema
body:
**Issue Description:**

After a recent update to drizzle-kit 0.20.0, we've encountered a critical issue where generating new SQL migrations results in the unintended dropping of all tables, with the exception of the last declared schema. This behavior is unexpected and deviates from our previous migrations, where all schemas were recognized and preserved accordingly.

**Configuration:**

We are utilizing the following configuration for our migrations:

```javascript
export default defineConfig({
  schema: "./schema/*",
  out: "./drizzle",
  driver: "pg",
  dbCredentials: {
    connectionString: env.DATABASE_URL,
  },
});
```

Our schema is based on the following structure:
```
schema
├── enums
│   └── enums.ts
├── shared
│   └── timestampColumns.ts
└── tables
    ├── bookingResources.ts
    ├── bookingServices.ts
    ├── ...
```

**Expected Behavior:**

The expected behavior upon generating migrations would be the recognition of all declared schemas and the preservation of their respective tables in the database.

**Actual Behavior:**

Only the last declared schema is recognized, and as a result, only one table remains post-migration, leading to the loss of all other tables.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

Update drizzle-kit to the latest version (0.20.0).
Run the command to generate new SQL migrations.
Observe that all tables except for the last one declared in the schema are dropped.
Impact:

This issue is critically impacting our development workflow and potentially could affect our production environment if not addressed promptly.

**Additional Context:**

This problem began after updating drizzle-kit to 0.20.0.
No errors are thrown during the migration generation; the tables are simply dropped.

title: There are three cases where drizzle-kit's introspect:mysql does not work.
body:
1. if default contains line breaks(\n\r)
```sql
CREATE TABLE `table_name` (
 `key` varchar(24) NOT NULL DEFAULT '　 aaa\r\nbbbb',
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8
```
The newline code causes a line break, which is invalid as typescript.

2.
```sql
CREATE TABLE `table_2` (
 `1st_key` tinyint(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
) 
```
This is an error because the beginning of the JavaScript key is a number.

3.
```sql
 `decimal_test` decimal(6,2) unsigned NOT NULL,
```
If the value is unsignded in decimal, the output will be as follows and an error will result.

```ts
decimal_test: decimal("decimal_test", { precision: 6, scale: 2) unsigne }).notNull(),
```

title: Option to specify or ask for migration name when creating one
body:
The developer experience of creating migrations could be improved if there was a way for us to specify what the migration name suffix should be.  Random names aren't particularly useful.
Currently we have to create the migration, then hunt around and change the filename, and then update the _journal.json file.

One improvement would be if the journal didn't include the suffix, as it can work out from the prefix number. Hence one less place to change.

But I suspect the easiest fix is to have an option to specify the name, and if not, ask on the console.

title: Drizzle cannot create composite primary key in migrations
Support for import aliases in drizzle-kit
body:
For some projects we use the helpful import aliases that typescript offers.
For example, in sveltekit, $lib maps to `src/lib` and is commonly used in imports.
In my case, my schema.ts file references some common constants in a file off $lib, and I (unwisely) had some custom column types declared in a file that also referenced other aliased paths.

When I try to create a migration I get an error like:
```
> drizzle-kit generate:sqlite

drizzle-kit: v0.19.13
drizzle-orm: v0.28.6

No config path provided, using default 'drizzle.config.ts'
Reading config file '/Users/redacted/drizzle.config.ts'
Error: Cannot find module '$db/schema'
Require stack:
- /Users/redacted/src/lib/server/db/db-helpers.ts
- /Users/redacted/src/lib/server/db/schema.ts
- /Users/redacted/node_modules/drizzle-kit/index.cjs
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1026:15)
    at Function.Module._load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:871:27)
    at Module.require (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1098:19)
    at require (node:internal/modules/cjs/helpers:108:18)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/redacted/src/lib/server/db/db-helpers.ts:7:25)
    at Module._compile (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1196:14)
    at Module._compile (/Users/redacted/node_modules/drizzle-kit/index.cjs:8623:30)
    at Module._extensions..js (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1250:10)
    at Object.newLoader [as .ts] (/Users/redacted/node_modules/drizzle-kit/index.cjs:8627:13)
    at Module.load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1074:32) {
  code: 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND',
  requireStack: [
    '/Users/redacted/src/lib/server/db/db-helpers.ts',
    '/Users/redacted/src/lib/server/db/schema.ts',
    '/Users/redacted/node_modules/drizzle-kit/index.cjs'
  ]
```
Ultimately, the solution/work-around for now is to separate the custom column types, and use relative import paths, but it would be good if drizzle-kit didn't need that.

It would be nice if there was way for drizzle-kit to understand import aliases. Either from the real tsconfig.json (which is complicated a little by sveltekit which uses `extends` to reference a file in `./.sveltekit/tsconfig.json` which defines the aliases:
```
{
	"compilerOptions": {
		"paths": {
			"$db": [ "../src/lib/server/db" ],
			"$db/*": [ "../src/lib/server/db/*" ],
			"$lib": [ "../src/lib" ],
			"$lib/*": [ "../src/lib/*" ]
		},
		"rootDirs": ... etc
```

Another option would be to allow path aliases to be added to `drizzle.config.ts`.

title: BUG: introspect:pg generates timestamp columns with mode: 'string'
body:
When I introspect an existing postgres database table with a timestamp column, it ges generated as { mode: 'string' } instead of a date.

```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "Entry" (
	"id" bigserial PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
	"userId" integer NOT NULL,
	"text" text NOT NULL,
	"timestamp" timestamp(3) DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP NOT NULL
);
```

```
drizzle-kit introspect:pg
```
```ts
export const entry= pgTable("JournalEntry", {
	id: bigserial("id", { mode: "bigint" }).primaryKey().notNull(),
	userId: integer("userId").notNull().references(() => user.id, { onDelete: "restrict", onUpdate: "cascade" } ),
	text: text("text").notNull(),
	timestamp: timestamp("timestamp", { precision: 3, mode: 'string' }).defaultNow().notNull()
}
```

Further, because of mode 'string', `entry.timestamp` is inferred as string, but the actual row returned by `db.select().from(entry)` contains a Date object, not a string.

Versions:
```
drizzle-orm: "0.28.6"
drizzle-kit: "0.19.13"
```

body:
Running `drizzle-kit introspect:mysql` on a planetscale database returns wrong primary key. 
This bug also breaks `drizzle-kit push:mysql` because the schema diff generated before trying to make changes is wrong.

I've tried to drop the entire planetscale database, recreate it from `schema.ts` with `drizzle-kit push:mysql`, and then do another introspect right after to check the result. It came out with wrong primary keys again.

Doing the above process with a local docker mysql worked fine, with no issue in pulling the primary keys.

Actual schema, generated with running `show create table [tableName]`:
```
CREATE TABLE `People`
(
    `PersonId`   int NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
    `FirstName`  varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `LastName`   varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `Employment` varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `Email`      varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `ClerkId`    varchar(40) DEFAULT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (`PersonId`),
    UNIQUE KEY `email_uniq_idx` (`Email`),
    KEY          `clerk_idx` (`ClerkId`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci

CREATE TABLE `TrainingRegistrations`
(
    `TrainingRegistrationId` int  NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
    `TrainingId`             int  NOT NULL,
    `PersonId`               int  NOT NULL,
    `RegistrationDate`       date NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (`TrainingRegistrationId`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci

CREATE TABLE `Trainings`
(
    `TrainingId`       int  NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
    `StartDate`        date NOT NULL,
    `EndDate`          date NOT NULL,
    `City`             varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `Venue`            varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `TrainingType`     varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    `TrainingCategory` varchar(50) DEFAULT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (`TrainingId`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4 COLLATE=utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci
```

Schema generated by `drizzle-kit introspect:mysql`

```
CREATE TABLE `People` (
	`PersonId` int AUTO_INCREMENT NOT NULL,
	`FirstName` varchar(50),
	`LastName` varchar(50),
	`Employment` varchar(50),
	`Email` varchar(50),
	`ClerkId` varchar(40),
	CONSTRAINT `People_PersonId` PRIMARY KEY(`PersonId`),
	CONSTRAINT `email_uniq_idx` UNIQUE(`Email`)
);
--> statement-breakpoint
CREATE TABLE `TrainingRegistrations` (
	`TrainingRegistrationId` int AUTO_INCREMENT NOT NULL,
	`TrainingId` int NOT NULL,
	`PersonId` int NOT NULL,
	`RegistrationDate` date NOT NULL,
	CONSTRAINT `TrainingRegistrations_PersonId` PRIMARY KEY(`PersonId`)
);
--> statement-breakpoint
CREATE TABLE `Trainings` (
	`TrainingId` int AUTO_INCREMENT NOT NULL,
	`StartDate` date NOT NULL,
	`EndDate` date NOT NULL,
	`City` varchar(50),
	`Venue` varchar(50),
	`TrainingType` varchar(50),
	`TrainingCategory` varchar(50),
	CONSTRAINT `Trainings_PersonId` PRIMARY KEY(`PersonId`)
);
--> statement-breakpoint
CREATE INDEX `clerk_idx` ON `People` (`ClerkId`);
```

And the typescript schema, generated by drizzle

```
export const people = mysqlTable("People", {
	personId: int("PersonId").autoincrement().notNull(),
	firstName: varchar("FirstName", { length: 50 }),
	lastName: varchar("LastName", { length: 50 }),
	employment: varchar("Employment", { length: 50 }),
	email: varchar("Email", { length: 50 }),
	clerkId: varchar("ClerkId", { length: 40 }),
},
(table) => {
	return {
		clerkIdx: index("clerk_idx").on(table.clerkId),
		peoplePersonId: primaryKey(table.personId),
		emailUniqIdx: unique("email_uniq_idx").on(table.email),
	}
});

export const trainingRegistrations = mysqlTable("TrainingRegistrations", {
	trainingRegistrationId: int("TrainingRegistrationId").autoincrement().notNull(),
	trainingId: int("TrainingId").notNull(),
	personId: int("PersonId").notNull(),
	// you can use { mode: 'date' }, if you want to have Date as type for this column
	registrationDate: date("RegistrationDate", { mode: 'string' }).notNull(),
},
(table) => {
	return {
		trainingRegistrationsPersonId: primaryKey(table.personId),
	}
});

export const trainings = mysqlTable("Trainings", {
	trainingId: int("TrainingId").autoincrement().notNull(),
	// you can use { mode: 'date' }, if you want to have Date as type for this column
	startDate: date("StartDate", { mode: 'string' }).notNull(),
	// you can use { mode: 'date' }, if you want to have Date as type for this column
	endDate: date("EndDate", { mode: 'string' }).notNull(),
	city: varchar("City", { length: 50 }),
	venue: varchar("Venue", { length: 50 }),
	trainingType: varchar("TrainingType", { length: 50 }),
	trainingCategory: varchar("TrainingCategory", { length: 50 }),
},
(table) => {
	return {
		trainingsPersonId: primaryKey(table.personId),

});
```

As you can see, `PersonId` is taken as primary key for all 3 tables, even if clearly it is not, and one of them doesn't even have such a column

title: `drizzle-kit generate:mysql --custom` ignores `--custom` flag

title: PostgreSQL - Remove DO $$ BEGIN ... END $$; wrapper
body:
In my drizzle-kit generated migration file, this type of statement fails, stating that the target table (`"article"` in this case) doesn't exist. However, the table creation statement exists well above this statement.

```sql
DO $$ BEGIN
 ALTER TABLE "article_cards_block" ADD CONSTRAINT "article_cards_block_article_id_article_id_fk" FOREIGN KEY ("article_id") REFERENCES "article"("id") ON DELETE no action ON UPDATE no action;
EXCEPTION
 WHEN duplicate_object THEN null;
END $$;
```

I tried removing all the `DO $$ BEGIN ... END $$;` wrappers around the `ALTER TABLE` statements that create foreign keys. The migration script completed without any errors, as opposed to the weird state I'd otherwise be left with, where only a subset of tables are created.

In the next version of drizzle-kit, please stop generating these `DO $$ BEGIN ... END $$;` wrappers around foreign key creation statements.

**I'd be more than happy to create a pull request if drizzle-kit was open source.**

title: [FEATURE]: drizzle-kit introspect should generate relation in generated schema.ts
[BUG]: composite primary keys on planetscale are always recreated
body:
### What version of `drizzle-orm` are you using?

0.28.6

### What version of `drizzle-kit` are you using?

0.19.13

### Describe the Bug

I have a table with a composite primary on a planetscale database

```
 CREATE TABLE `Follow` (
    `followerId` char(24) NOT NULL,
    `followingId` char(24) NOT NULL,
    `createdAt` datetime(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT current_timestamp(3),
    PRIMARY KEY (`followerId`, `followingId`),
    KEY `Follow_followingId_idx` (`followingId`),
    KEY `Follow_followerId_idx` (`followerId`)
) ENGINE InnoDB,
  CHARSET utf8mb4,
  COLLATE utf8mb4_0900_ai_ci; 
```

Using introspect I have 

```
 --> statement-breakpoint
CREATE TABLE `Follow` (
    `followerId` char(24) NOT NULL,
    `followingId` char(24) NOT NULL,
    `createdAt` datetime(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3),
    CONSTRAINT `Follow_id` PRIMARY KEY(`id`)
);
```

so drizzle sees a migration (generating migration file): 

```
ALTER TABLE `Follow` DROP PRIMARY KEY;--> statement-breakpoint
ALTER TABLE `Follow` ADD PRIMARY KEY(`followerId`,`followingId`);--> statement-breakpoint 
```


Looking at made queries by drizzle-kit, I have found that this query causes the issue 

```
const tablePks = await db.execute(
        `SELECT table_name, column_name
  FROM information_schema.table_constraints t
  LEFT JOIN information_schema.key_column_usage k
  USING(constraint_name,table_schema,table_name)
  WHERE t.constraint_type='PRIMARY KEY'
      and table_name != '__drizzle_migrations'
      AND t.table_schema = ?`,
        [inputSchema]
      );
```


replacing left join with inner join fixes this issue

```
const tablePks = await db.execute(
        `SELECT table_name, column_name
  FROM information_schema.table_constraints t
  INNER JOIN information_schema.key_column_usage k
  USING(constraint_name,table_schema,table_name)
  WHERE t.constraint_type='PRIMARY KEY'
      and table_name != '__drizzle_migrations'
      AND t.table_schema = ?`,
        [inputSchema]
      );
```


### Expected behavior

Introspect gives corresponding schema on composite primary keys

### Environment & setup

I am on planetscale and I run drizzle-kit `introspect` than `generate:mysql` (I except to have no migration but I have one on all composite primary keys)

import type { Config } from 'drizzle-kit'

export default {

├── drizzle-kit@0.19.13

title: Allow skipping the confirmation prompt for the `drizzle-kit push` command
body:
There is currently a `--strict` flag to always prompt for confirmation. It would be useful to also have a flag to always skip the confirmation prompt for cases where interaction is not viable. E.g., cleaning up a local DB in the CI after integration tests have been run.

More generally, it would also be useful to have a top level configuration key to disable interactive mode across all commands. Is this something you would consider adding?

title: Error: type "serial" does not exist
Purpose of `_meta` directory
body:
It is unclear what the `_meta` directory is used for as there is no documentation for it (and the source code is not available yet, see https://github.com/drizzle-team/drizzle-orm/issues/580). Currently I wonder if it has to be checked in to git, and under what circumstances it is required to read from as well as write to this directory.

This would influence how drizzle migrations can/will be deployed on production: Does have to be part of the deployed code, can it be non-existent, is it only needed for ephemeral data or does it have to persist (i.e. in docker this would have to be a mounted volume), is it sufficient to only read from there (i.e. in docker this would allow increased security by marking the filesystem as readonly) etc...

title: [BUG]: generate:pg ignores all but one onDelete: 'cascade' modification per table
body:
### What version of drizzle-orm are you using?
0.28.5

### What version of drizzle-kit are you using?
0.19.13

### Describe the Bug
I'm using postgresql, and this is a table in my schema:

```ts
export const chartDriveCharts = pgTable('chartDriveCharts', {
	id: serial('id').primaryKey(),
	driveChartPath: text('driveChartPath'),
	chartId: integer('chartId').notNull().references(() => charts.id),
	driveChartId: integer('driveChartId').notNull().references(() => driveCharts.id),
})
```

I modified this table to add `{ onDelete: 'cascade' }` to both `chartId` and `driveChartId`.
I ran `drizzle-kit generate:pg`.
The generated migration SQL looks like this:
```sql
ALTER TABLE "chartDriveCharts" DROP CONSTRAINT "chartDriveCharts_chartId_charts_id_fk";
--> statement-breakpoint
DO $$ BEGIN
 ALTER TABLE "chartDriveCharts" ADD CONSTRAINT "chartDriveCharts_chartId_charts_id_fk" FOREIGN KEY ("chartId") REFERENCES "charts"("id") ON DELETE cascade ON UPDATE no action;
EXCEPTION
 WHEN duplicate_object THEN null;
END $$;
```

The `{ onDelete: 'cascade' }` was only added to the first modified column, and it should have applied to both.
Note: I added this to all the other foreign keys in my schema. All the other tables with only one foreign key generated the correct SQL. The tables with two foreign keys only generated SQL for one of the columns.

Inability to Revert Migrations in Drizzle
body:
### Problem Description

In TypeORM, reverting a database migration is straightforward due to the `up()` and `down()` methods generated with each migration file. Drizzle, however, lacks this essential feature, making it difficult to rollback database schema changes.

#### Steps to Reproduce

1. **Initial Schema**: Assume we have a table `TODO` with fields `{id, title}`.
2. **Add Field**: Add a new field `description` to the `TODO` table so that the schema becomes `{id, title, description}`.
    - Generate a migration file and migrate changes to the database.
3. **Attempt to Revert**: Now, let's say you want to revert these changes to `{id, title}`.
    - Run `drizzle-kit drop` to choose which migration file to delete. Assume you remove the last generated file that adds the 'description' field.
    - Run the application to try and revert the schema change. This fails to revert the database to `{id, title}`.

#### Issues Encountered

1. Drizzle doesn't offer an automatic way to revert migrations.
2. After dropping the last migration file, generating a new migration file via `drizzle-kit generate:{dialect}` results in an empty file. This is because Drizzle checks the last migration file and the current schema, both of which are `{id, title}`, thus seeing no changes to migrate.

#### Suggested Improvement

Implement functionality similar to TypeORM’s `up()` and `down()` methods to facilitate easy migration rollbacks.

### Note
I would have contributed this feature myself, but unfortunately, Drizzle-kit doesn't seem to be open source.

title: Concern about Unauthorized drizzle-kit push Commands
body:
### Issue Description:

#### Summary:

I'm using `drizzle-kit` for database operations. I'm concerned about securing the database against unauthorized `drizzle-kit push` commands that could alter the schema or data.

#### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run `drizzle-kit push:pg` from the shell.
2. Notice that the database schema can be modified without additional verification of user credentials or roles.

#### Expected Behavior:

There should be some form of protection or verification to ensure that only authorized developers can run `drizzle-kit push` commands that modify the database schema or data.

#### Possible Solutions:

1. Implement a two-factor authentication mechanism before accepting `push` commands that modify the schema or data.
2. Introduce a digital signature verification for schema changes, where only approved digital signatures can execute schema-altering commands.
3. Create an authorization layer that works independently of the database or front-end technology, requiring explicit permission for schema modifications.
  
#### Additional Context:

The `db:push` command is currently executed from `package.json` as follows:
```json
"db:push": "drizzle-kit push:pg"
```

Would be great to hear if you have any recommendations or if this is in the pipeline for future releases.

title: `.primaryKey()` isn't picked up when updating an existing table.
body:
Creating a new table on our schema:

```ts
export const testTable = pgTable("test", {
  id: uuid("id")
    .default(sql`extensions.uuid_generate_v4()`)
    .notNull()
    .primaryKey(),
  name: text("name"),
});
```

Correctly generates the sql migration (With `PRIMARY KEY`):

```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "test" (
	"id" uuid PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT extensions.uuid_generate_v4() NOT NULL,
	"name" text
);
```

But if I start with the following schema

```ts
export const testTable = pgTable("test", {
  name: text("name"),
});
```

And then **add the `id` property**, I get the following migration (Nothing about the primary key):

```sql
ALTER TABLE "test" ADD COLUMN "id" uuid DEFAULT extensions.uuid_generate_v4() NOT NULL;
```

I would expect the sql migration to also set `id` as the primary key, but I had to manually add the following SQL statement to our migration:

```sql
ALTER TABLE "test" ADD PRIMARY KEY ("id");
```

Sharing it here so that others can be aware of it, and hopefully be fixed!

Environment:
- Adapter `drizzle-orm/pg-core`
- Command: `drizzle-kit generate:pg`
- drizzle-kit: v0.19.12
- drizzle-orm: v0.27.2

title: [Mysql] Drizzle kit generates invalid SQL syntax for `onUpdateNow` when an `fsp` is provided to timestamp
body:
Say you have the following table with a timestamp:
```typescript
export const users = mysqlTable("users", {
  id: char("id", { length: 26 }).primaryKey().notNull(),
  updatedAt: timestamp("updatedAt", { mode: "date", fsp: 3 })
    .onUpdateNow()
}
```

The generated SQL with `drizzle-kit generate` command will be:
```SQL
CREATE TABLE `users` (
	`id` char(26) NOT NULL,
	`updatedAt` timestamp(3) ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
);
```

But this is invalid syntax with the following result:
```sh
code: 'ER_INVALID_ON_UPDATE',
  errno: 1294,
  ...
  sqlMessage: "Invalid ON UPDATE clause for 'updatedAt' column"
```

According to the Mysql [documentation](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/timestamp-initialization.html):

> If a [TIMESTAMP](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/datetime.html) or [DATETIME](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/datetime.html) column definition includes an explicit fractional seconds precision value anywhere, the same value must be used throughout the column definition.

And then it says:
> This is not permitted:
CREATE TABLE t1 (
  ts TIMESTAMP(6) DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3)
);

So the correct SQL should be:
```SQL
CREATE TABLE `users` (
	`id` char(26) NOT NULL,
	`updatedAt` timestamp(3) ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(3),
);
```

I renamed one of my tables, and I found that the generated SQL is trying to drop constrains on the new table instead of the old names:

```sql
ALTER TABLE "posts_to_images" DROP CONSTRAINT "post_image_post_id_post_id_fk"; -- Trying to drop on "posts_to_images", but this table doesn't exist! The correct table is "post_image"

ALTER TABLE "posts_to_images" DROP CONSTRAINT "post_image_image_id_image_id_fk";

ALTER TABLE "post_image" RENAME TO "posts_to_images"; -- It's only there that "posts_to_images" is known
```

The rest of the querry is correct however. I'm using Drizzlekit 0.19.12 and DrizzleORM 0.28.1.

title: `introspect` Creates a `schema.ts` File with Unused Imports
body:
Upon running `introspect:pg` this evening, drizzle-kit did it's thing and created a `schema.ts` file successfully. However, it included named imports in the file which aren't used in the schema.

For anyone running a strict `tsconfig.json`, that's a problem which requires manual intervention. Not ideal for automation. Here's what was imported:

```
import { pgTable, pgEnum, pgSchema, AnyPgColumn, serial, bigint, boolean, timestamp, uuid, text, jsonb, integer } from "drizzle-orm/pg-core"
```

With these two being the offenders `pgSchema, AnyPgColumn`. I'm not exactly keen on having to have another `tsconfig.json` in the directory to turn off strictness just for drizzle, either.

title: Invalid `jsonb` default value for `introspect`
body:

```
metadata: jsonb("metadata").default('{}'::json).notNull(),
```

For what it's worth, that column is created as such:

```
metadata jsonb NOT NULL DEFAULT '{}'::jsonb,
```

title: control infer mode for timestamp columns in `drizzle-kit introspect:pg`?
body:
Hi,

first of all thanks for all the amazing work around drizzle and drizzle-kit. I really love the developer experience <3

However, I am having an issue with the `drizzle-kit introspect:pg` command. I can't find a way to control the way timestamp columns in my DB are handled upon introspection/schema generation.

The [drizzle docs](https://orm.drizzle.team/docs/column-types/pg#timestamp) state that there are two types of 'infer modes' one can specify: `date` or `string`. In my case, I would need the `date` infer mode, as I use Dates in my application instead of parsing strings (I use Next.js with tRPC and superjson as the [transformer](https://trpc.io/docs/server/data-transformers) to work around the Date object JSON serialization issue when transferring data between server and client).

My temporary workaround to get what I want is to remove all occurrences of `mode: 'string'` from my schema file after running `drizzle-kit introspect:pg`. What is the proper way to do this?

title: Support for bun:sqlite
body:
Drizzle ORM works with bun:sqlite, which is very nice.
However, DrizzleKit has no support for it yet. Since better-sqlite3 does not work on Bun, using Drizzle with bun:sqlite is not really possible. Applying migrations works, but generating them is currently not available AFAIK.

Any plans on supporting it in the future? Maybe I am doing something wrong, any idea or `drizzle.config.ts` sample?

Adding an option like `--host 0.0.0.0` similar to  `drizzle-kit studio --port 1234` could solve the problem.

title: Running studio config don't accept mysql2 driver
[BUG]: Data loss warning when changing varchar size
body:
Changing a VARCHAR size shouldn't cause the table to truncate (At least in `pg` and `mysq`l) but:
 ```
Warning  Found data-loss statements:
· You're about to change name column type from varchar(191) to varchar(255) with 2 items
· You're about to change logo_url column type from varchar(191) to varchar(255) with 2 items
· You're about to change ad_city column type from varchar(191) to varchar(255) with 2 items
· You're about to change ad_first_row column type from varchar(191) to varchar(255) with 2 items
...

THIS ACTION WILL CAUSE DATA LOSS AND CANNOT BE REVERTED
```
From `MySql` [specification](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/alter-table.html) under operation that support the `INPLACE` algorithm:
>As of MySQL 8.0.14, changing a column character set, when these conditions apply:
> - The column data type is [CHAR](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/char.html), [VARCHAR](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/char.html), a [TEXT](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/blob.html) type, or [ENUM](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/enum.html).
> - The character set change is from utf8mb3 to utf8mb4, or any character set to binary.
> - There is no index on the column.

Context:
drizzle-kit: `v0.19.12`
db: `planetscale`

title: Wrong syntax for MySQL composite primary key
body:
drizzle-kit is generating a wrong syntax SQL code on create table with multiple primary keys.

By following the documentation, we can create a simple table with two primary keys like this:
```typescript
export const usersToGuilds = mysqlTable('users_to_guilds', {
    userId: int('user_id'),
    guildId: int('guild_id')
}, (table) => ({
    pk: primaryKey(table.userId, table.guildId)
}));
```

The generated SQL code is:
```sql
CREATE TABLE `users_to_guilds` (
	`user_id` int NOT NULL,
	`guild_id` int NOT NULL,
	CONSTRAINT `users_to_guilds_user_id_guild_id` PRIMARY KEY("user_id","guild_id")
);
```

The part `PRIMARY KEY("user_id","guild_id")` should use back ticks instead of double quote for table columns:
```sql
PRIMARY KEY(`user_id`,`guild_id`)
```

---

Furthermore, the documentation says that the result query should be:
```sql
CREATE TABLE `users_to_guilds` (
	`user_id` int NOT NULL,
	`guild_id` int NOT NULL,
        PRIMARY KEY(`user_id`,`guild_id`)
);
```
The CONSTRAINT part should be added into the doc (?)

---

Using `drizzle-orm@0.27.2` and `drizzle-kit@0.19.4` with `mysql2` driver.

title: `push:sqlite` does not recognize `--schema` option
body:
## Context
* drizzle-kit: v0.19.2
* drizzle-orm: v0.27.0
* pnpm: v8.6.3

## Setup
* run `pnpm exec drizzle-kit push:sqlite --schema=./schema.ts --driver=better-sqlite --url=./test.db`

## Issue
Running the command result in an error `error: unknown option '--schema=./schema.ts'`

Current `drizzle-kit` [documentation](https://orm.drizzle.team/kit-docs/commands#prototype--push) list param `schema`  as required, but result of running the command with `--help` **does not** list `--schema` as an option
```sh
$ pnpm exec drizzle-kit push:sqlite --help
Usage: index push:sqlite [options]

Options:
  --config <config>                      Path to a config.ts file, drizzle.config.ts
                                         by default
  --tableFilters                         Table name filters
  --connectionString <connectionString>  SQLite connection string
  --driver <driver>                      SQLite database path
  --url <url>                            SQLite database path
  --auth-token <authToken>               SQLite database path
  --verbose                              Print all statements for each push
  --strict                               Always ask for confirmation
  -h, --help
```

`schema` can still be specified and perform `push:sqlite` successfully through configuration file.

title: `generate:sqlite` generates invalid migration statement for integer field that use auto-increment
[Request] Check DB before trying to truncate table
body:
I was wondering if it was possible for drizzle-kit to query the database when trying to push a new schema to check if the data inside is maybe already compatible.

As it is right now, drizzle-kit will just give you the option to wipe the whole table when you're for example lowering a varchar's length and try to push that schema.

It doesn't matter if all the data inside the database already conforms to the new schema, it'll still try to truncate the table. 

I'm sure doing this for every changed schema property would result in a lot of extra work, especially when there are multiple different databases that need to be supported. 

Admittedly the way it works now isn't the end of the world since you can just dump the whole table beforehand and fill it up again but having drizzle-kit handle this automatically would still definitely be a nice quality of life improvement.
